title: Comparative Educational Study on Scientific Inquiry and Clinical Intervention Learning Using Computer and Manikin Simulations

context.prior_knowledge: Comprehension of basic medical/life science concepts (cell physiology, fluid circulation, etc.), fundamental emergency response principles (trauma management, basic resuscitation), foundational scientific experimental design and data analysis (hypothesis formulation, variable control, statistical validation).
context.additional_context: An integrated course combining computer simulations accessible via smartphones and mannequin-based practical training in limited environments, comprehensively evaluating learners' observational skills (monitoring vital signs), measurement abilities (recording experimental data), and analytical skills (statistical processing) while emphasizing the scientific inquiry process. Special emphasis is placed on variable control and evidence-based conclusion drawing.

learning_goals: Learners can observe physiological variables (blood pressure, respiratory rate, cardiac output, etc.) of virtual patients in computer simulations with ≥80% accuracy and select evidence-based diagnoses and interventions (e.g., medication, surgical procedures).

Learners can perform emergency response protocols (CPR, airway management, etc.) with ≥70% success on mannequin simulations, systematically analyze experimental data (biometric signals, response times, etc.), and derive evidence-based conclusions.

Learners can compare ≥3 advantages/disadvantages of LAMMPS and COMSOL simulation tools for molecular dynamics and fluid mechanics scenarios, select the appropriate tool based on evaluation criteria (accuracy ≥80%, computational efficiency <10 minutes, usability ≥4/5), and provide a 500±50-character rationale following the scientific inquiry method (problem definition–hypothesis–design–analysis–conclusion).

constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
